fields.headline: Tribute song
fields.bodyText: Teenage Kicks was John Peel's favourite song (Letters, October 30) and has been played all week by radio stations up and down the country. How about reissuing it as a tribute, with all proceeds going to charities chosen by his family. Paul Davy Menston, W Yorks Can I echo the call to remember John Peel's producer, John Walters. It was this John who formulated the invaluable rule "never eat, nor attend, anything spelt F-A-Y-R-E", which I have followed to this day. Michael Woodgate Exeter, Devon Re Simon Hoggart's observations on football chants (October 30): in 1989, shortly after the fatwa had been issued, Leeds United fans taunted Bradford City supporters with the politically savvy chant of "One Salman Rushdie, there's only one Salman Rushdie". Jeremy Lascelles London You say that "the last time they met on screen, Omar Sharif was a small dot riding out of a desert mirage to join Peter O'Toole ..." In fact they met on screen five years after Lawrence of Arabia in Anatole Litvak's 1967 film The Night of the Generals. John Hodson Bolton, Lancs O'Toole and Sharif reunited in 1990 for The Rainbow Thief, directed by cult Chilean filmmaker Alejandro Jodorowsky (of El Topo fame) - though it has never been seen in the UK, it is an often remarkable comic fantasy. Brad Stevens Luton, Beds Your leader (October 30) reminds me of the man who refused to alter his clock to BST in March on the grounds that the extra hour's daylight would fade his curtains. Rev Tony Bell Chesterfield, Derbys
